Subject : Letaposs spend £m on the NHS insteadThis works out to £.bn a year, but because the number is entirely wrong itaposs actually £.bn. Either way, the NHS funding gap is about £bn a year and growing.Youaposll note they didnapost say the EU costs us each p a day, letaposs spend it on the NHS instead. Subject : Brave new trade deals Secondhand bassoons, jumpers from the Faroe Isles, and selling the NHS to Donald Trump. Let us say no more about it. Subject : The will of the people This one is still occasionally mentioned, although in increasingly-quieter voices. Because the will of the people has, for the best part of two years, been solidly Remain. Leave constituencies have voted in Remain campaigners, there were more Remain than Leave MEPs elected last month, and everyone whoaposs not a blind, bonkers Tory can see Brexit has gone the way of the Norwegian blue. Today, what theyaposre not telling you is that John Major was once considered the most pathetic, grey, boring, rudderless, bastard-beset, pea maniac Prime Minister weaposve ever had. And he is now the Tory Partyaposs best hope.While Vanilla bitchslaps Marmite on the TV hustings, a man once ridiculed by the entire nation for being a middle-aged Clark Kent without the superpowers has snapped his power pants back on and declared heaposll wrestle either one of them to their political death.Stop staring at our potential PMs for a moment, asking yourselves how it is possible these two unappetisers are the best the natural party of government can offer. Marvel instead that the voice of sanity now looks and sounds a lot like an aged Mr Bean. Sir Johnaposs reputation has changed since he left Downing Street. We have since been exposed to claims that he shared bathwater, among other things, with Edwina Currie.Once upon a time that was one of the more shocking political sex scandals. It was news that made people stop eating their dinner with their fork halfway to the mouth, their eyes widening as they said: Wha  But those were more innocent times.  Major was the last Tory PM to defeat the anti-European wingnuts in his own party. In  he signed the Maastricht Treaty, the deal which helped to form the modern European Union.The fact he won that fight is the reason a more youthful Nigel Farage left the Conservative Party. It is why, a year later, UKIP was founded by an economist. And a little after that, a faction led by Farage ousted that leader on the grounds he was too intellectual.To be fair, then, this is very much Majoraposs fight. If you criticise David Cameron for running away, mild-mannered Major should be praised at least for coming back.It must be coincidence that Mad Cow Disease is coming too.   We all know proroguing Parliament, and making laws only a minority want, is undemocratic. But by threatening a judicial review, Major has exposed the fact itaposs un-Tory, too.No patriot should seek to destroy civil institutions that work just fine. No democrat should hold the people to an opinion they no longer hold. And no Tory should f*** business. Prostitutes, pigs, secretaries - these are all, sadly, expected. Perhaps even Edwina, in extremis. But Brexit means destroying Parliamentary sovereignty, promising a total lack of border control, ignoring the will of the people and wasting billions of pounds on schemes we currently enjoy with % cashback.   Boris Johnson will tell you to be optimistic about all of that. Jeremy Hunt says it must happen. Both of them are wrong. Because John Major, for all his flaws, are all the things they are not.He is a former Prime Minister. He is an election-winner. He defenestrated Margaret Thatcher. He saw off the Eurosceptics. He survived not only ridicule but the worldaposs worst Currie.And he s bearing the Brexit kryptonite - facts, democracy, the rule of law, and good old British sovereignty which says we are ruled by the Parliament, the courts, and the governments we choose. Not emotion, wish-fulfilment, or a government imposed upon us by the insane. But Supeaman is not alone. There are millions of us, from all parties, classes, and walks of le. And you donapost need X-ray vision to see that Brexit is up to no good.

title: businessmans dream home cost him
story: NewsBusinessmans dream home cost him his marriage - and could soon see him JAILEDEddie McIntosh has spent more than a decade at war with Powys council in Wales in a planning dispute over his eco retreatShareCommentsByAnna Lewis:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsEddie McIntosh at his eco retreat in Powys, Wales "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA businessman lost his marriage - and potentially his freedom - after his plans to build a dream countryside home turned into a nightmare. Eddie McIntosh has endured more than  years of anguish because of a legal wrangle over planning permission for the lavish development. And he could yet be jailed over the affair. The farming entrepreneur set up his eco retreat in rural Powys, Wales, in . His planning dispute with Powys council has so far cost the local authority £, in legal fees after a court case against Eddie held earlier this year.Eventually, it will also eventually see the farmer go to jailhe continues refusing to pay the fine he was issued, Wales Online reports.Now, the -year-old has opened up about the exhausting struggle for survival after being granted planning permission to keep his business only months after being told to tear it all down.    Eddie said: Itaposs been absolutely devastating. The amount of things Iaposve had to go through - my we and I have split, the business suffered, I lost the plot a little bit. Iaposm looking forward to getting back on track, especially considering years ago I was being nominated for best off-grid retreat and was on TV with Kevin McCloud. In  Eddie came across the -acre abandoned smallholding by accident. He had recently sold a Grade-II listed building in Gloucester and with about quarter of a million pounds behind him, he was looking to buy a lestyle in a rural setting. Driving through Powys in his motorhome, he saw an auction sign for the property and decided to buy it. His vision was to restore the land, establish a new smallholding and create an off-grid rural retreat offering education and alternative therapies for visitors. But just as his vision started taking off, it was forced to grind to a halt after planning permission was refused.    Eddie said: People look at me and think I didnapost submit planning permission in the first place but I did. I submitted it and it kept getting rejected so I piled on as much pressure on as possible. The bizarre thing is that these people never wanted to talk to me in the first place. They never discussed my project, it was only ever enforcement and legal action. In , Mellowcroft smallholding received a planning enforcement notice demanding Eddie take down everything from his treehouse home to the recycling point and classroom for visitors. The notice came only a year after his business had began to boom, and after featuring on Kevin McCloudaposs Man Made Home programme on Channel . Eddie said: It started just spiralling out of control. I have spent £, on planning applications and enforcement notices.  I wasnapost trying to hide anything, it was in the media and on my website. By , Eddieaposs planning application had been turned down and told his appeal was equally unsuccessful. Eventually, the planning inspector ruled the entrepreneur only had permission to use the site for agricultural purposes - meaning he would have to demolish the structures on the land and cease living in his home. Eddie insists he did comply with the order by the October  deadline, although he carried on living there, but thought he would be able to reuse some of the structures for agricultural purposes. He was eventually charged with  offences under the Town and Country Planning Act , all of which he denied. On February , a jury found him guilty of all charges following a four-day trial at Merthyr Crown Court. He was fined £ and told once more to stop living on the site - and remove all structures.    Eddie said: I tried to represent myself and that went wrong but couldnapost get legal aid. I am not going to pay the fine, I canapost pay the fine so I have to do the  days [in prison]. Iaposm not paying the costs on the moral principle that there was no charge to answer in the first place. Last Thursday, five months after Eddieaposs appearance in court, the Mellowcroft smallholding went up in front of the Powys Council Planning Committee one last time. On this occasion, it was for retrospective planning permission for agricultural purposes only. Perhaps unexpectedly, the application for the existing welfare cabin, silver birch sap production and storage building, farm office, storage shed and hut was granted - meaning Eddie will no longer have to tear down the structures that he lost his fight in court for. In total, a freedom of information request revealed Powys County Councilaposs legal costs to bring the matter to court mounted to £, - along with the £, it had previously cost them in enforcement action. Eddie said: Itaposs unbelievable to think [the council] have spent £, and itaposs just come to nothing.  It seems like a ludicrous farce really.

Tragic Paige was stabbed repeatedly by twisted killer John Leathem at a deli in Clydebank in March . Pamela, , who has set up a charity in Paige’s memory, told the Daily Record: “The messages are absolutely vile and what makes it worse is the fact that it was set up using my daughter’s name.    “They were sent to our charity page and I was shocked and horried at the content. “I just can’t understand why someone would want to do something so awful and use pictures of my children with horrendous messages across them. “Every day of our lives, we have to deal with losing Paige and people who do this type of thing should think of the pain and hurt it causes grieving families. “To hide behind a computer and send abuse of this kind is just callous, cruel and unacceptable.”    Pamela, also mum to Andrew, , Peyton, seven, and three-year-old Lucas, is now calling for tougher laws to unmask and trace online trolls. title: horrific true story behind act
story: NewsHorric true story behind The Act which drove daughter to kill her own mumHulus The Act, starring Joey King and Patricia Arquette tells the chilling true story of Dee Blanchard and daughter Gypsy Rose which ended in murderShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsDee Dee said her daughter was unable to walk or eat "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn their small community, the devoted mother and her severely ill daughter were well known and cherished. Everyone sympathised with single mother Dee Dee Blanchard, who spent every moment caring for Gypsy Rose, a teenager with “the mental capacity of a seven-year-old”.Confined to a wheelchair almost her entire le, her daughter suffered from leukaemia , asthma, muscular dystrophy, learning dficulties and paraplegia, according to Dee Dee.She also had to be fed through a tube after having her saliva glands removed and her teeth fall out from seizure medications. Whenever they went out, the mother had to carry her oxygen tank and feeding tube.    Andthat weren’t enough suffering, the family had been left with nothing after Hurricane Katrina, from which the mother and daughter had barely escaped with their lives. Their ordeal, though, had led to an outpouring of support from their community of Springfield, Missouri, charities and celebrities. Habitat for Humanity built them a house with a special wheelchair ramp, while the Make-A-Wish Foundation sent them on an all-expenses-paid trip to Disney World. Country music star Miranda Lambert visited them at their home and, moved by their plight, gave them £, from her personal account. And they met Lord of the Rings actor Elijah Wood, posing with him for a photo. But appearances weren’t what they seemed. The horrying true crime story has now been told in Huluaposs The Act, starring Joey King and Patricia Arquette.    On June , , sherf’s deputies entered Dee Dee’s home and found the motheraposs body, facedown in a pool of blood from stab wounds inflicted several days earlier.Neighbours had called police after someone hacked into the mother’s Facebook account, and wrote: “That bitch is dead”.More alarming, there was no sign of her daughter, leading to a belief Gypsy Rose had been abducted by her mother’s murderer. The medications she needed to stay alive were found still in the house and a huge manhunt was launched. Officers were at first relieved to find Gypsy Rose in a hotel with her boyfriend Nicholas Godejohn, who she had met online. But what they discovered next was so bizarre it was even more shocking and grotesque than the idea that someone had murdered a loving mother and snatched her severely handicapped daughter. Gypsy Rose wasn’t a child at all but a -year-old adult. And she had never been sick, disabled or confined to a wheelchair. In fact, once her boyfriend had butchered her mother, she had simply stood up from her wheelchair and run out the house with him.  It was actually the mother, not her daughter, who was sick it emerged. Dee Dee suffered from a condition called Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy , a mental disorder where a parent fabricates or induces a person under their care to obtain sympathy or attention. She had been making her daughter pass herself off as younger, and pretend to be disabled and chronically ill, giving her medication she didn’t need and subjecting her to unnecessary surgery, and controlling her through physical and psychological abuse. The incredible story has now been turned into a true crime mini-series, The Act, starring Patricia Arquette and Joey King. In fact, Gypsy Rose had been trying to escape her abusive, controlling mother for years. Four years earlier, in , she ran away, fleeing from the hospital to a friend’s house. But Dee Dee tracked her down and punished her, taking away her phone, smashing her computer and hitting her with coat hangers.  In a  interview, she said: There are certain illnesses that I knew I didnapost have. I knew that I didnapost need the feeding tube. I knew that I could eat. I knew that I could walk. But I did believe my mother when she said I had leukemia. Gypsy Rose also told police her mother would shave her head to make her look like a chemotherapy patient and convinced medics to remove her saliva glands by using an anaesthetic to numb her gums and make her drool before doctor visits. Tubes were also implanted in her ears to control the ear infections her mother claimed she had. She also claimed thatshe ever said something while in public which showed she was not really sick or mentally impaired, Dee Dee would give her a very tight squeeze - then when the two were alone, would strike her with her hands or a coat hanger. Then, in , she started a secret romance with Nicholas Godejohn, who was six years her senior, after meeting on a Christian dating site.  Soon, they were planning their wedding and naming their future children. Most importantly, Gypsy Rose saw in Godejohn an escape from her controlling mother. In , she convinced her internet boyfriend to murder her mother so they could be together. “I wanted to be free of her hold on me,” she told his trial in . Godejohn drove to Springfield, arriving while Gypsy Rose and her mother were away at a doctors’ appointment. After they had ed and Dee Dee had gone to sleep, she let him into the house, handing him duct tape, gloves and a kne, before hiding in the bathroom and covering her ears so she would not have to hear her mother screaming as he stabbed her to death. Then, they fled to Godejohn’s house is Big Bend, Winconsin, where police caught up to them, and the real specics of the case were unraveled.  In , Gypsy Rose was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to  years in prison. According to her loved ones, Gypsy Rose is actually thriving in prison. Kristy Blanchard, Gypsy Roseaposs stepmother, said in : Despite everything, she still tells me that sheaposs happier now than with her mom. And thatshe had a choice to either be in jail, or back with her mom, she would rather be in jail. In another interview from prison earlier this year she said she felt “like a prisoner” before her mother was killed. She said: “The prison that I was living in before, with my mom, itaposs, like, I couldnapost walk. I couldnapost eat. I couldnapost have friends. The three -year-old boys spent a night in a police cell before they their parents picked them up, according to reports. Police spokesman Peter Elke said: “After we determined that two of the group members are  years old and therefore are not criminally responsible, we handed them over to the parents. “The three -year-olds were arrested and detained overnight. They were released on Saturday after interrogation. A police investigator who wanted to remain anonymous told local media that an arrest warrant “had no chance of success in this case”.

title: neil armstrong says final descent
story: NewsNeil Armstrong says final descent to Earth was fraught with computer problemsReclusive first man on the moon Neil Armstrong died aged  in , but here, in the first of two parts, we reveal the build-up to and drama of the moon landings in his own words...ShareCommentsBySara Wallis:,  JUL NewsAstronaut Neil Armstrong became the first man to walk on the Moon, July ,  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith one small step, , miles above us, Neil Armstrong became the most famous man on the planet. But the first man to set foot on the moon -  years ago this month - was also notoriously shy and, once back on Earth, lived a reclusive le out of the spotlight, rarely speaking about the mission, even with friends and family. Even photos taken from the surface of the moon only show his fellow astronaut Buzz Aldrin, as it was Armstrong who took them and preferred to stay behind the camera. Armstrong died aged  in  but here, in the first of two parts, we reveal the build-up to and drama of the moon landings in his own words...    We were trailing. The Soviet Union had successfully put firstly an articial satellite into space, and secondly, put a man into orbit around the Earth. We had put only one flight, Alan Shepard, on a short -minute suborbital flight of about a hundred miles altitude and back down into the ocean. We’d never had a person in orbit, and now the President was challenging us to go to the moon. The gap between a -minute up and down flight and going to the moon was something that was almost beyond belief technically. But Nasa had identied the lunar landing as perhaps the only way we could catch up with the Soviet Union. And the challenge was enormous.    The first Apollo space craft was on a pre-flight test with the crew in the module atop the rocket on the pad at Cape Canaveral. A spark ignited some of the flammable material in the cockpit. The hatch was an inward opening hatch that the crew was unable to quickly open, and the crew was killed in the fire. It was a tragedy, and it was going to take us a long time to recover from that. The second flight was an eleven day flight to make sure that the command module had systems that would run for theof the lunar mission. That worked well. They decided they would take the next flight - Apollo  - on the big Saturn rocket, and not only fly it with humans on it but also take it around the moon. It was an enormously bold decision, but that moved our programme along a lot further. A few days later the boss called me and said, “Would you take the third flight down the road, Apollo  ” A month before the launch of Apollo  we decided we were confident enough that we could try an attempt a descent to the surface.    I thought we had a % chance of getting back down to earth on that flight, but only a   chance of making a successful landing on the first attempt. I never allowed myself the luxury of dreaming of being the team which would step foot on the moon. On the day of the launch, there was a certain relaxed atmosphere. You’re thinking, “We’ll get down to two minutes and then they’ll call a hold, then they’ll cancel the flight then we’ll go another day, so don’t get too excited here about this”. So, actually, when you actually lt off, it’s really a big surprise. The noise at lt off from the pad is extremely loud, you get not only the noise of the engine but the reflected noise that’s coming up off the ground. Until you fly out of that reflection after about  seconds it’s very dficult to hear anything, even with our special helmets and earphones on.    It’s a very shaky ride especially in that particular rocket, the Saturn , a , tonne machine with an energy enough to lt it off the pad. The second and third stages are just as smooth as the first stage is shaky. It was a striking event, leaving the planet and realising that there was no logical reason that you were ever going to fall back to that planet at some point. It was a slowly changing panorama as you went from just the horizon to a large arc, to a larger and larger arc, and finally to a whole sphere. The Earth is quite beautul from space. It looks quite small and quite remote, but it’s very blue and covered in white lace, the clouds, and the continents are very clearly seen. Greenland stood out, just as it doesn’t on the globe in your library, all white. Africa was quite visible, and we could see sun glint off a lake. There were a just thousand things to worry about in the final descent to the moon. It was hardest for the systems, it was hardest for the crew. It was the thing I most worried about, because it was so dficult. The unknowns were rampant. And in the middle of the descent our computer complained at us that it was having a problem. We had gone that far and we wanted to land.    We were getting good velocities and good altitudes. The navigation was working fine. There were no anomalies other than the fact that the computer was saying, ‘Hey, I’ve got a problem’. My inclination was to keep going ahead as long as everything looked like it was fine. So we continued on toward the landing site, but then the computer showed us where it intended to land and it was a very bad location. It was on the side of a large crater, about  metres in diameter with very steep slopes covered with very large boulders, not a good place to land at all. So I took over manually and flew it like a helicopter, out to the west, a smoother area with not so many rocks. We started losing visibility when we got a little below  feet. We starting picking up dust, and not just normal dust clouds like we would experience on Earth. This sheet of moving dust obscured the surface almost completely. This very fast, almost horizontally moving sheet of dust did not billow up at all. It just moved out and away in a straight radial sheet. The visibility continued to decrease as we got lower. I was able to get it down there safely before we ran out of fuel - we had about  seconds of fuel left. After landing we took a handshake - “Congratulations, we made it this far”. But there was a lot of work to do at that point, and we couldn’t luxuriate on those feelings. “Houston, Tranquility Base here. The Eagle has landed.” That was the signature line for achieving the presidential goal that we had been working on for a decade, and in our view that was a very important statement. Days: To The Moon And Back is on Wednesday  July on BBC at pmApollo aposs Key Mission Moments LaunchApollo  was the most powerful rocket to fly successfully. The five F engines produced . million pounds of thrust – the equivalent of  F- fighter jets. The crew were accelerated to almost ,mph. Seeing the eclipseOn the fourth day, as Apollo  neared the Moon, it entered its shadow and got their first close up views of the Moon’s surface and the spectacle of a solar eclipse. Entering lunar orbitTo enter lunar orbit, the crew of Apollo  had to slow the craft by around ,mph by burning their engine. The timing was critical an overburn of just a matter of seconds might slow the Command Module enough to crash it. Seeing the far side of the moonAs the crew began to orbit the Moon they became some of the first people to see its far side. Only the crews of the earlier, pathfinder missions, Apollo  and Apollo  missions had been there before them. Moon LandingAs Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin were making their descent to the Moon’s surface, they lost radio contact with mission control. They had become so low on fuel they came within less than a minute from having to abort the mission. The lunar module touched down safely but it was four miles downrange from the planned site. MoonwalkToward the end of his historic moonwalk, Armstrong’s heart rate shot up to an alarming  beats per minute. Not wanting to alert the world to the problem, mission control made a disguised request for Neil to slow down by checking equipment. The broken switchAldrin and Armstrong might have been stranded on the Moon. They discovered that one of the switches controlling the engine had broken off. Eventually, Buzz Aldrin armed the switch with a felt-tipped pen. Re-entry to Earth’s atmosphereThe astronauts relied on Earth’s atmosphere to slow them down on the trip home. But the angle at which they entered was critical with a margin of less than three degrees.

title: woman wearing gym gear asked
story: NewsWoman wearing gym gear humiliated as supermarket security asks her to cover upAmandine Gaudin was shopping when she was told her outfit was too bare for the stores tasteShareCommentsByElaine McCahillDeputy News Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsAmandine Gaudin was asked to cover up because she was wearing gym gear to her local supermarket "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman claims she was told to aposcover upapos by a supermarket security guard because she wore gym gear to the store. Sports coach Amandine Gaudin was shopping in Carrefour Etampes when she was humiliated by a security guard after a customer complained about her outfit.In a Facebook post that has since gone viral, Amandine said: I was doing my shopping quietly at Carrefour Etampes when the security manager came to see me...to warn me not to come back dressed like this.It was too bare for their taste, she later added.    Her post included a picture of her posing in front of the store in a bright blue crop top and leggings. Speaking to BFM, she said: I was coming home from work and I decided to go shopping in preparation for my birthday. I was wearing sportswear, because of where I work. On this occasion I was wearing leggings and a sky blue sports bra.    A manager then comes to see me and tells me that the next time, that I come to do my shopping in this store, it will be necessary that I wear another outfit, that I will have to cover myself more . Amandine finished her shopping and asked to see the manager when she got to the till. An employee then told her that her outfit was too bare for their taste and she would have to wear a T-shirt before going to to the store the next time. She continued: I have been shopping there for years and often wore that outfit without any problems. According to the manager it was a customer who saw me in the aisles that complained.

title: arbroath woman scales new heights in fundraising effort for cystic fibrosis trust
story: Sisterly love reached new heights at the weekend as Lisa Marshall raised money for Cystic Fibrosis Trust.The -year-old’s brother Robbie, , was diagnosed with the condition when he was just weeks old and ever since Lisa has fund-raised to help with research.On Sunday, though, her ambition to help took her to dizzying heights as she donned a hard hat and harness and abseiled down the Forth Rail Bridge.Lisa was completing the abseil with her boyfriend, Brad McKerchar, who is also Robbie’s best friend.Lisa, an optometrist director at Specsavers in Arbroath, said: “I am raising money for cystic fibrosis as it is very close to my heart as my brother Robbie has the condition.“He was diagnosed three weeks after birth due to a failure to thrive.“I chose to take part in the abseil as it is so important to raise money for cystic fibrosis and fight for a cure.“I have always been eager to raise awareness and money for the illness.“From an early age I helped my Mum sell charity Christmas cards at AK Bell Library in Perth to raise money for the trust, and last year at my work we raised money by doing a charity bake sale. We constantly have a collecting can in the practice.“I am also hoping to do a sky e in the future.“In total we have so far raised £ but donations are still coming in which is fantastic.“I had hoped to raise £.”Orkambi is the second drug to be licensed for use in people with cystic fibrosis, the first was Kalydeco.The medication is not currently available on the NHS with the Cystic Fibrosis Trust currently campaigning to ensure the drugs reach the people who need them.However, the medication cannot help everyone with cystic fibrosis and can only help those with specic mutations of the condition.Lisa added: “Orkambi will not help Robbie as he has a rare mutation and the most common, both of which can’t be helped by Orkambi, so I feel the more money raised to go towards research which will help everyone who suffers is paramount in order to help him.”Although to some an abseil would be extremely daunting, Lisa said she really enjoyed herself.“I loved every moment of it, it was very exciting.“It was amazing at the top and we could spot all of our supporters easily as they were all in cystic fibrosis yellow!“I was watching Robbie all the way down as he was cheering us on.”Lisa and Brad were joined by  other daredevils who were raising money for cystic fibrosis and luckily the skies were clear for the venture over the River Forth.

title: benjamin siegrist looking to make history as he aims for top flight place
story: Benjamin Siegrist was flattered to be linked with a move to the English Championship over the summer.But other than to the Premiership with Dundee United, the Swiss goalkeeper isn’t planning of going anywhere for quite some time.Siegrist’s performances in the second half of last season, culminating in a string of five-star displays during the promotion play-offs, saw him watched by Nottingham Forest.That was nice to hear as he enjoyed a few weeks off last month but, as he focuses on the coming season with the Tangerines, fans will be delighted to learn it’s not turned his head.“It was nice but it just proved the point to me I know what I can do and I know where the standards lie,” he said.“I am more than happy here. I know what I have here and I work well with the staff.“I know how big a club this is and I am really happy to be here.“And what is important for me is I want to be one of those players who go in the history books of this club and say he was one who got promotion for the team.“I want to improve and learn every week. As a team I think we got better last season as the games continued and I think I got better as a goalkeeper.“We want to keep doing that this year and,we do, we will get back to where we want to be.“Everybody knows where this club belongs and everybody wants to be part of achieving that ultimate goal of getting promoted.“That’s a big point of incentive and motivation for all the players.”Siegrist admits a bonus for him as he ed to work last week was teaming up again in training with fellow-goalie Deniz Mehmet.He was at United until January and has ed with a view to signing up again.“We crossed paths before when we were younger, at international tournaments with Switzerland and Turkey.“Coming from clubs down south we also faced each other. We are competing for the same place but there is always the goalkeepers’ union that means we stick together and it is nice to be working every day with someone you like.”Very much one for looking forward, Siegrist refuses to dwell too long on the disappointing end to last term that saw United again miss out on promotion in the play-offs.And when he does look back, he takes the positives.“I think what happened last year is part of our motivation for this year but I don’t want to speak too much about it because we start from zero again for a new season.“You do every year. In terms of experience it is good that we have had big games, big occasions together and that will help us.“It is like money in the bank but this season is about doing it consistently and picking up points over the whole of the year.”Tonight sees the start of a busy weekend when the entire squad will be involved in a friendly at Brechin before heading for Dumbarton tomorrow to do it all again.Two games in less than  hours may seem unusual but, for Siegrist, it will be the perfect way to prepare for the start of the competitive action in the Betfred Cup at Hearts next week.“So far as fitness goes we are good and game time is the most valuable time you have as a player,” he added.“You can train all week butyou don’t have a game at the end of it you are not bringing everything you’ve worked on together.“It is good to have as many games as we can so we are looking forward to these two games.“There is a lot more to football than passing and running, so game time is the most valuable part of pre-season.”

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowArgyll College UHI#s doors have been opened to the public to display the hard work of its talented students.The staff room was filled with colour and pattern thanks to the amazing display of crafts donated by the students of NC Art and Design and HNC Contemporary Art. Made from sustainable and recycled materials, the mouse sitting atop a weak mushroom symbolises the fragility of the environment.Ali Mackie#s collection uses a iety of techniques and materials to make four distinct pieces about dferent aspects of her le that inspired her.Other pieces jump out at you, like Maureen Clerk#s D rendering of cup and ring marks well known to Kilmartin Glen and the standing stones and Julie-Anne Mather#s simplied abstract oil painting of a dried out root on Tiree that reminded her of a womb.One student, Patrycja Madej, displayed her printmaking talent for the course and enjoyed it enough to go back the following year for her HNC.Patrycja said: #My prints are reduction printmaking, which means they were made with lino and with more than one colour. title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

Once we got the racing underway everything flowed along very well indeed and there was some fantastic racing for all to watch.#He added: #Everyone connected with the club had an absolute awesome weekend at Kilmartin, and the place was buzzing.#It was especially great to see such a large number of spectators who made the effort to come along to watch, and after speaking to a few of them they seemed to have enjoyed themselves as much as we did .#Special mention and thanks must go to Jonathan McLeod who was the driving force behind this event, and without his enthusiasm and effort this would not have happened.#We also need to thank the three unsung local workers Ronnie, Jamie and Johnny ,who along with Jonathan all put a tremendous amount of work into the track over the last couple of weeks, cutting down all the bracken by hand on the hill areas, cutting grass and all round general work to ensure this race meet went ahead.#Ricky Caldwell concluded: #The riders are excited about coming back next year # so watch this space.#

title: borderlands-boost-as-historic-deal-signed-off
story: A NEW poundm growth deal for the Scottish Borders and wider Borderlands region has been signed today.Representatives from the UK Government, the Scottish Government and five councils that represent the region were in Peebles on Monday to sign the Heads of Terms for investment of the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal.The deal is seeking to attract tourists to the area and boost business, and is the result of collaboration between the Westminster and Holyrood Governments and local authorities in the region.It is hoped that the investment will create more than , jobs within the Borderlands region.Infrastructure Secretary Michael Matheson said: ldquoI am delighted we have reached this important milestone in signing Heads of Terms for the Borderlands Deal.ldquoSuccessful delivery of the deal will create jobs, protect existing ones and extend the benefits of economic growth to even more communities across Scotland.ldquoAlongside the establishment of a new enterprise agency for the south of Scotland, and activities of the South of Scotland Economic Partnership, the Scottish Governmentrsquos pound million investment will deliver signicant and lasting benefits right across the region.A full cross border feasibility study in to bringing the Borders Railway to Hawick, Newcastleton and on to Carlisle also forms part of the deal.Transport agencies either side of the Border will work on a cross-border study for the A corridor as well as exploring an integrated transport system.The package of investment will also include broadband and mobile signal investment designed to bring the region up to UK wide levels of connectivity and a Borderlands Energy Investment Company to generate cheaper energy for the region and help the Borderlands become the first carbon neutral region in the UK.A pound million Mountain Bike Innovation Centre in the Tweed Valley aims to establish a world-class destination for research, development and tourism around mountain biking.John Lamont, MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, said: ldquoThis is fantastic news for the Borders ndash this deal is packed full of projects which will boost the Borders economy.ldquoFor too long, the Border at Berwick has been viewed as this line which prevents collaboration.ldquoIt is great to see this deal ignoring this Border and looking at how the whole region can be better served, and the economy better supported.ldquoEvery penny of this pound million investment is set to benefit the whole Borderlands region by bringing in thousands of jobs, millions more visitors and improving connectivity.ldquoI am particularly pleased that the Borders Railway extension will receive this pound million boost for a full study into how we can bring the line to Hawick, Newcastleton and on to Carlisle.ldquoLess tangible but equally important is the investment in broadband, tourism, business and energy which the whole of the Borders is set to benefit from.Scottish Secretary David Mundell said:ldquoItrsquos fantastic news that the UK Government is to invest up to pound million in the Borderlands Deal.ldquoThis is an ambitious approach to cross-border working between Governments, local authorities and partners which will boost economic growth by helping existing business, encouraging new ventures and bringing a wealth of improvements to people who live and work in the area and to visitors.ldquoThe Borderlands Deal has made huge progress in the last  months.ldquoId like to thank the five lrmlocal authorities who have worked so well together, along with the UK and Scottish governments, to achieve this.ldquoThe south of Scotland and northernmost parts of England operate as a single economic area and it is important the border is not allowed to become an obstacle to development.South Scotland Labour MSP and Scottish Labourrsquos Shadow Cabinet Secretary for Infrastructure, Connectivity and Transport, Colin Smyth, has welcomed the news but warned that the Borderlands deal will not provide a quick fix for the challenges facing the region.He said: ldquoHaving been involved in the Borderlands since the beginning, Irsquom pleased to see this deal finally agreed as it has been a long time coming.ldquoThe five local councils deserve enormous praise for developing the projects and getting to this stage, given that many people predicted it would be impossible to bring councils from across the border together in this way.ldquoEveryone now needs to get on with delivering the projects.ldquoThis will not be a panacea for the regionrsquos massive economic challenges.ldquoIt works out at around poundm a year over ten years for the whole of the south of Scotland which is quite modest.ldquoHowever, it will bring some badly needed investment into projects that could make a real dference to the local economy.

title: campaigners-ignored-as-eildon-housing-approved
story: CAMPAIGNERS say their concerns ldquofell on deaf ears after Scottish Borders Council approved a controversial planning development on the foot of the Eildon Hills.Rural Renaissance, the contracting arm of Melrose-based JS Crawford property developers, wants to build  homes on the Croft, near Dingleton Road, Melrose.Some of the new properties would tower m about the height of Dingleton Road, and the council has so far received  objections and representations.However, councillors sitting on Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee, which met on Monday July , opted to stick with planning officerrsquos recommendation to approve the development.Speaking at the meeting on behalf of the lsquoDonrsquot Build on the Eildonsrsquo campaign group, Melrose resident Carrie Henderson told councillors: ldquoBad design has been compounded by certain stipulations made in the planning brief.ldquoThe requirement for a road to loop around the nursery, when combined with the awkward levels on the site, have results in plans for houses on the southern slopes being some  metres higher than the level of the road.ldquoBe in no doubt, this housing estate will be dominant, intrusive and jarring. It will be an eyesore.Philip Neaves, from Edinburgh-based Felsham Planning and Development, spoke on behalf of Rural Renaissance.He said: ldquoThe Croft is an allocated development site that was allocated in .ldquoThe reporter who allocated the site would have been well aware of the sensitivity of the site but has still allocated it.ldquoWhat we have is proposals for  houses for private sale and seven affordable housing units.ldquoThe site, when viewed from Melrose, appears as part of the settlement, not the countryside, and views of the site from the Eildons are limited.ldquoThere are signicant economic benefits to the development, not just for employment during the construction phase but for nearby residents as well.Nearly all of the councillors expressed reservations about the development, but only one, Galashiels councillor Sandy Aitchison, voted against the proposals.He told the committee: ldquoThe fact is the reporter has made a big mistake here and the land should never have been allocated for housing in the first place.ldquoFurthermore, I donrsquot like the fact wersquove got affordable housing as a token gesture, itrsquos not spread out in the site and there are no family homes."Do people who need affordable homes not have families ldquoThere are so many objections. Many are from where and they are asking us to step in and protect this site which we as a local authority are charged with protecting.ldquoI really object to this application for a number of reasons.Melrose and Leaderdale councillor Tom Miers, who chairs the committee, also criticised the proposals but said he believes it can be acceptedthe council imposes certain planning conditions: ldquoI have real problems with the design and concept. I think the houses at the back are much too high and they stick out too much.ldquoThe middle three in particular, which will be at the back of the site, should be reduced in height.He suggested that the houses be reduced, by way of a planning condition, from three storey houses down to two storey.All councillors except councillor Aitchison were in agreement, and as he failed to find a seconder for his motion to reject the application, the proposals were granted planning permission without the need for a vote.Speaking after the meeting, Ms Henderson said: ldquoOver  people objected to this development and yet in the end it felt like their opinion counted for nothing. Todayrsquos decision is obviously a huge disappointment for them.ldquoUnfortunately, the planning committee couldnrsquot, or wouldnrsquot, see past the fact that this site is in the local plan.ldquoThe arguments we put forward that the proposal for the Croft is sub-standard and would irrevocably scar the view of the Eildons fell on completely deaf ears and the committee happily waved it through.ldquoFuture generations will look back and wonder how it was possible that a housing estate was ever allowed to be built on the beautul Eildons. But by then, of course, it will be too late.ldquoThe members of the planning committee, bar the one councillor who objected, should be ashamed of themselves for the decision they made today.

title: homophobic-selkirk-man-ordered-to-pay-compensation-to-couple
story: A LABOURER from Selkirk has admitted hurling homophobic abuse towards two men.Then a month later Andrew Gillie approached both and told themthey didnt drop charges he would kill them.The -year-old of Buccleuch Road, pleaded guilty at the towns sherf court to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner and making abusive and homophobic comments in Yarrow Terrace, Selkirk, on August .He also admitted a charge of threatening the two men in Bridge Street, Selkirk, on September .Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said the first incident happened at .pm when the two men, who are in a relationship with each other, became aware of Gillie and a female standing on a pavement.Gillie made a homophobic comment about one of the men.Mr Fraser said: "He is fed up being targeted about his sexuality and was alarmed at what had taken place."The fiscal said Gillie had been cautioned and charged over that but came across the two men at about .pm on September  when they were walking their dog.Mr Fraser said: "He said you better drop the charges or I will kill you. Not surprisingly they were alarmed by this."Defence lawyer Robert More said his client had not realised the implication of interfering with justice and how serious a matter that could be.He said: "It was an indication of his ignorance which was evident in the first instance when he was trying to impress his friends. One of the gentlemen had lived in his block and thats how he knew him."Having been charged he was extremely foolish and approached them."Gilie was ordered to pay a total of pound in compensation to the two men and fined pound.Sherf Peter Paterson warned him of the consequences of any further intimidating behaviour towards people over their sexuality whether they be male or female.

title: tesco-defends-food-donation-changes
story: BOSSES at Tesco in Galashiels have defended a move which has taken donated food away from local foodbanks.Several foodbanks in the central Borders previously benefitted directly from donations being collected close to the checkouts.But a deal with FareShare has seen distribution handed over to the Edinburgh-based charitable organisation.And now all donations, as well as surplus fresh produce, are sent to a depot in Edinburgh for distribution.A foodbank insider told us: "In the past deposits were collected directly by the local foodbanks here in the Borders."If we want to benefit from these donations now we have to sign up to FareShare."Several local foodbanks have been affected by the change.But bosses at Tesco Extra are urging all local groups - including all foodbanks - to sign up to their benefits scheme.A spokesman explained: "We donate surplus food every day to local charities and community groups through our Community Food Connection scheme.ldquoWe would encourage these charities in Galashiels to apply to be part of the scheme."There is no cost associated and all food is donated free of charge."Foodbanks in the central Borders also have regular in-store collections days.The spokesman added: "Local charities can also apply to host a food collection in the store."As well as donated items FareShare Central  South East Scotland takes surplus food that canrsquot be sold in shops, either because of packaging errors or a short shelf le.The produce, which is still good to eat, is then redistributed to frontline charities and community groups.The Edinburgh based depot, which is run by partner charity Cyrenians, currently serves a network of  organisations across central and south east Scotland.There are currently  groups in the Scottish Borders on the distribution list, including school breakfast clubs, a domestic violence refuge, and older peoplersquos lunch clubs.FareShare Central  South East Scotland Manager, Lynne Collie, told us: ldquoTimes are tough for charities, with local authority cuts continuing to bite."The food we redistribute is great quality and tastes just like the food yoursquod eat at home."Itrsquos amazing that we can take something that could been thrown away and turn it into something that creates enormous social benefit.FareShare last year provided enough food for almost one million meals - worth over pound million to the charity sector in savings - which helped to feed , people every week.

title: drink-driver-going-wrong-direction-galas-one-way-system
story: A MOTORIST was spotted by police driving the wrong way in a one way system in Market Street, Galashiels, during the early hours of December .And when stopped by police Jason Metcalfe was found to be over the legal alcohol limit.But the -year-old from Sandy in Bedfordshire, claimed he was forced to drive the vehicle by another man whose we the car was registered to and he was afraid of him.Metcalfe pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to driving with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes - the legal limit being .Not guilty pleas to having no insurance, no MOT and failing to comply with a road sign were accepted by the Crown.Defence lawyer Greg McDonnel said his client was told he had to drive the vehicle.But he accepted in law coertion was a high test to reach and Metcalfe had pleaded guilty to the drink driving offence.He was banned for  months and fined pound.

title: galashiels-man-accused-driving-four-times-legal-limit
story: A GALASHIELS man has been accused of driving while more than four times the legal alcohol limit after allegedly being involved in a domestic disturbance.Twenty six year old Lee Burrell appeared from custody and pleaded not guilty to a total of six offences said to have happened at a house in Langlee Drive on Wednesday.He denied driving with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes - the legal limit being .Burrell also pleaded not guilty to failing to identy the driver of a car to police, refusing to give a sample of breath, behaving in a threatening or abusive manner, wilfully or recklessly breaking a light covering in a common stair in Langlee Drive and struggling violently with three police constables.Burrell - who gave an address in Glendinning Terrace - will stand trial on August  with an intermediate hearing on August .

title: convoys-planned-a72-resurfacing
story: THE final works on the A between the Nest roundabout and Walkerburn are due to take place next week.The Holylee to Thornilee section of the road will be resurfaced on Thursday and Friday .However, the road will remain open, with a convoy system in place between am and pm.It follows a three-day closure this week on the same section of the A for essential patching ahead of the resurfacing.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe would like to thank the travelling public for all their patience with this weekrsquos closure which allowed the workers to operate in a safe manner without the risk of passing vehicles.ldquoBy allowing the road to be closed, it means the works could be carried out much quicker.ldquoThe road will remain open on July  and  during the resurfacing but motorists are advised to expect delays.

title: jinski-end-scottish-tour-galashiels
story: BASED on Tyneside, indie folk duo Jinski are song writer Stephen Wegrzynski and musician Dave Kennedy.The partnership forged from acoustic roots and the love of a strong melody is heading to Galashiels next month.Their music touches the borders of folk, country, and pop, keeping alive the song writing tradition whilst remaining resolutely modern.Playing lsquoliversquo with just two voices and two guitars Jinski have been touring the UK, honing their craft, chalking up the miles and making new friends wherever they play.They have built a reputation for delivering music for the head and the heart that is full of passion, meaning and originality.In the last few years Jinski have released two full studio CD albumsand a  vinyl only EP Live Long.Their albums deliver memorable tunes with a cutting lyrical edge, taking the little things that matter and revealing the bigger picture.Guest artists have included the English accordion queen Karen Tweed, New Rope String Band member Pete Challoner , Jez Lowersquos pipes and piano man Andy May and stalwart Neil Harland on double bass.All their albums have been produced and recorded by Dave Maughan .Notable live supports in recent years have been to Lindisfarne, The Proclaimers, Joe Jackson, Kathryn Tickell, Eliza Carthy and Mark Radclfe.They have also recently appeared on BBC  The One Show.Now Jinski are set for a -date tour of Scotland which will climax with a show at the MacArts on Friday, August .Tickets, priced at pound, are now on sale from the MacArts box office on  .Doors open at .pm.

title: galashiels-building-site-artwork-best-scotland
story: SEVEN Galashiels schools are celebrating after winning a national construction competition with a mural in Galashiels.The brightly coloured artwork at Eildon Housing Associations Huddersfield Street development site has been crowned as one of the winners of the  Ivor Goodsite Hoarding Competition.As part of the Considerate Constructors Scheme, the competition aims to fuel childrens interest in the construction industry.The collaboration saw pupils from St Peters, St Margarets, Stow, Burgh, Tweedbank, Langlee and Clovenfords primary schools collaborate in the concept, design and painting stages to produce a champion end product.Pupils also chose the theme of the artwork, and decided to showcase the reasons why they love living in the Scottish Borders.Alison Lowrie, Hart Builders and Eildon Community Benefits Officer presented the schools with their award.She said: "I am so pleased for all the children that took part. It has been a brilliant multi-school project with whole schools getting involved, from planning and designing to painting the amazing artwork."There was fierce competition with  entries from across the UK and Ireland, so for our site to be one of the winners is absolutely fantastic."What talented future artists we have in the Borders."

title: rallying-cry-support-innerleithen-bike-festival
story: INNERLEITHEN residents have come out in force to support biking events in the town following recent criticism by a group of local homeowners.Last week the Peeblesshire Newscovered a meeting of Innerleithen Community Council at which five residents used the public open forum to complain about last months Transcend Biking Festival.Following this report, many members of the Innerleithen community took to social media hitting out at the claims and praising the event, which was attended by thousands of bikers worldwide.Moves are afoot to make Innerleithen the mountain bike mecca of Europe - including a pound million investment to create world-class facilities.But following the catalogue of complaints aired by the small group of residents, a strong message has been voiced to the community ndash ldquoletrsquos embrace whatrsquos coming to us.Transcend was TweedLoversquos first instalment of the bike and music festival in the town.And it is being hailed a success for not only creating a jam-packed programme for bike-mad riders of all ages, but breathing le back into the quiet town and boosting the economy.Fears are growing that biking festival organisers will simply move these types of events from the townfaced with continued backlash.Innerleithen was once described as ldquoa poor cousin to Peebles and Glentress for mountain biking and tourism, but is now on its way to becoming the national hub for outdoor events.Following our article, Tom Veitch, who resides in Montgomery Street not far from the location of the festival, said: ldquoWe didnrsquot get the leaflets which were apparently posted through some doors about the traffic management plans and parking, but to be honest it was fairly self-explanatory. Apart from the cones on the street, we never had any issues with bad parking or disturbance from people attending the event.ldquoI could hear some music on the evenings but I liked the atmosphere and it certainly wasnrsquot a nuisance. We did attend the family ride on the Sunday, and while there was plenty of mud, I thought theyrsquod done a great job creating such a big event in its first year in Innerleithen.With the proposed plans to redevelop the old mill to create the Mountain Bike Innovation Centre, Tom added: ldquoI think its exciting times to be a resident in Innerleithen and I hope events like these continue to grow and do well here.ldquoI remember when Innerleithen was a poor cousin to Peebles and Glentress as an MTB and tourist destination, and I think itrsquos the hard work of local people who have brought Innerleithen to the fore. Most people are excited about the prospects and possible future developments here, and Irsquod hate people to get the wrong impression of the overall community support based on the reported views of a few people who were disturbed in the eventrsquos first year.ldquoHaving said that, I hope the organisers take on board the negative feedback and incorporate improvements into any future events. I know they were in touch with the community council earlier this year before the event, hopefully theyrsquoll keep up this close relationshipthey come back.Meanwhile, Allan Graham who has lived in the town all of his le said without events such as Transcend, the Innerleithen community has nothing.He added: ldquoThe mills have all gone and what we have is biking, walkers etc. Letrsquos embrace whatrsquos coming to us and make the most of it.Jamie Birks echoed this sentiment adding: ldquoThe town has a real and deserved opportunity to be a national hub for outdoor events such as this. So much talent and experience from so many organisations, coupled with truly amazing natural resources that could make such a positive impact on the town ndashwe all want it.Innerleithen Community Council has promised to pass on the complaints raised at the meeting to event organisers, Scottish Borders Council and Police Scotland.But Chairman Marshall Douglas said the community council ldquostrongly supports the Transcend Bike Festival and will continue to work closely with event organisers to ensure the future success of the event.

title: cops-ask-help-catch-boy-racers-galashiels
story: POLICE in Galashiels have called on a local supermarket to help them catch boy racers.For months there have been reports made about young drivers gathering at the Tesco car park.And now officers have asked the firm to take down registration details to help them track down the culprits.PC James Harrison said: ldquoWe are still receiving calls about boy racers in the car park at Tesco on a Saturday night.ldquoIt seemed to get better for a while, but the problem is still there. We are working with young people to teach them about safe driving and we have asked Tesco to keep us informed on what is happening.ldquoWe have asked them to take down any registration plates of cars that are causing problems, or give us any faces from the CCTV cameras.PC Harrison also said he had recently given tickets to drivers for performing lsquodoughnutsrsquo ndash spinning the car to produce circular marks on the ground ndash in the Netherdale area.

title: german-leader-angela-merkel-seen-shaking-third-time-month
story: German Chancellor Angela Merkelrsquos body shook visibly at a public event for the third time in less than a month on Wednesday, but the leader insisted that there is nothing to worry about.Mrs Merkel shook as she stood at a military honours ceremony alongside Finnish Prime Minister Antti Rinne in Berlin, listening to the two countriesrsquo national anthems.----It followed similar episodes on June  and June . As in both those cases, the incident started as she stood still without talking, and the -year-old recovered quickly as she started walking.The first incident happened in near-identical circumstances as she stood alongside Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy at a military honours ceremony. The weather that day was hot, and Mrs Merkel said afterwards that she was fine after drinking three glasses of water.The second incident happened at the German presidentrsquos palace as she listened to his comments on the swearing-in of a new justice minister. Temperatures were much cooler that day, as they were on Wednesday.--vw,vw,px, px"The hands of German Chancellor Angela Merkel as she listens to the national anthem --Mrs Merkel, who has been German leader since , turns  on July . She suggested that the psychological impact of the first incident was responsible for the subsequent episodes.ldquoI am fine, she told reporters after her meeting with Mr Rinne. ldquoI said recently that I am in a phase of processing the last military honours with President Zelenskiy. That is clearly not entirely complete, but there is progress.She added: ldquoI will have to live with it for a while now, but I am very well and people donrsquot have to be worried.The health of public figures is generally regarded as a private matter in Germany and the countryrsquos privacy laws are very strict on that type of information. It is not publicly knownMrs Merkel has any health problems.The Chancellor has a reputation for stamina garnered in years of late-night domestic and European negotiating marathons. She has rarely had to cut back her work schedule signicantly, though she did so for a few weeks in  when she cracked her pelvis while cross-country skiing in Switzerland during a winter holiday.--German Chancellor Angela Merkel was seen shaking again --Mrs Merkel demurred when asked at a news conference whether, given recent concern about her health, she should now take a more head-on approach to the issue.ldquoMy comments on this are done today, and I think my statement that I am fine can find acceptance, she said. ldquoI said that I have to process this event and that I am in this process, and I think that just as it came, it will go away one day.She added: ldquoI am very firmly convinced that I am entirely capable of performing..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: German leader Angela Merkel seen shaking for third time in month

story: Kintyre Sea Sports, working  in conjunction with Dalintober Beach Group and many other local groups, will be staging Campbeltown Community Regatta again this year # after all the good work last year the  event is eagerly anticipated.The  regatta will take place on Saturday August  from am till pm and there will be opportunities for everyone to try out a iety of sea sports and beach activities.The sea sports on offer will be canoeing, dinghy sailing, kayaking, sailing in larger yachts, stand-up paddle boarding, sub-aqua ing, in the pool at Aqualibrium and wind surfingconditions permit.There will be beach games again on Dalintober Beach.A spokesperson for the regatta team said: #It is an opportunity for everyone to try out these activities and also a chance for those already proficient to join in with others having fun on the water or on the beach.#It is open to local people and visitors of all ages from five upwards, but remember that some activities will have age limits on them and will be available to those of eight-years-old or more.#And, best of all, the sports are free for all participants.There will be refreshments available at very reasonable rates on Dalintober Beach and at Campbeltown Sailing Club.More details will be revealed as the big day approaches, so keep an eye on the Courier and the Kintyre Sea Sports web page, where, closer to the event, there will be an online booking form.

title: letter insufficient consultation on pylon scheme
story: I was out and about in Tarbert recently getting updated by my constituents and local businesses on many pressing local issues.With the village of Tarbert heading into the busy tourist season, the lack of parking spaces in certain areas will become more and more prevalent, all the more so with the ever increasing amount of traffic going towards Islay.I will continue to seek local advice on how to resolve Tarbert#s parking challenges and make sure they are relayed on to our roads department.While the upgrades to the electrical grid capacity are much needed I have been listening to concerns about the plans to erect numerous huge pylons along the picturesque Tarbert skyline.Many locals have commented that there has been insufficient public consultation and many of my constituents have pointed out that with some changes to pylon positioning much of the adverse visual impact could be mitigated.I have also been sent pictures and videos of the cemetery road which has numerous large potholes and craters.Many Tarbert residents have informed me thatwe, in the council, cannot help to provide a solution then a community solution should be looked at.It was great to catch up with local residents in Tarbert and I look forward to being back there very soon.Coucillor Alastair Redman,

title: course record equalised by 21 year old golfer niels
story: A total of  players started the rd Gents# Championship last Saturday, June , with the second leg of the four-round competition played on Sunday.Defending champion Greg Watson pulled out of his title defence owing to injury and it was widely regarded that the competition this year would be fierce with multiple winners, including Stuart Campbell and George MacMillan, in the field alongside more recent victors Oliver Armour and Revie Thomson.However, it was -year-old Niels Andersen who well and truly grabbed the headlines after the first round. Niels resides in Calornia where he plays golf on the college circuit but he was raised in Campbeltown where his mum still works in the local hospital.He has been a member of Machrihanish Golf Club for  years since the age of four. Always a very promising junior, Niels announced his arrival in style at the championship on Saturday.His round began rather innocuously with a bogey five at the world-famous first hole. However, he followed that bogey by birdieing the second, third and fourth holes to take him to two-under-par through four.Another birdie on the eighth took him out in  shots, three under par. Turning for home, his round really caught fire with a fantastic eagle three at the par-five th.He then birdied the th and th to take his score to seven under par after  holes.The course record at Machrihanish is held jointly by George MacMillan and Stuart Campbell at seven-under-par s and Niels had the record firmly in his focus as he came down the home stretch.The disappointment of a bogey five at the tough par-four th was soon extinguished with a birdie two at the short th as Niels continued to blaze a trail over the magnicent Old Tom Morris-designed links.His sizzling round continued with assured pars at the th, th and th holes to finish with a course record equaling seven-under-par .A club spokesperson said: #This is an incredible achievement by the young golfer, whose record will take pride of place on the wall beside the cards of great champions, Stuart Campbell and George MacMillan, in the new clubhouse once it is ready.#George started his round early on Saturday and was the leader in the pro-shop after his own fantastic round of two-under-par . The round looked good enough to lead until Niels’s  came in later. Six times champion George had no fewer than seven birdies of his own to get off to a terric start.In third place after round one was -time champion Stuart who had a good day with an excellent two-over-par  gross leading a clutch of players who had s and s as the low scores came rolling in with the beautul Machrihanish sunshine.The second day started wet and windy and, while the rain dried up, conditions were much trickier and this was reflected in the scoring as the famous old links really bit the players back.Best gross on day two was shared by Matthew MacAulay and round one leader, Niels, who both had seven-over-par s.George hit the ball extremely well in the conditions but fell one shot further behind Niels after his eight-over-par . Stuart lost a little more ground after a nine-over-par  on the tough second day.The third and fourth rounds of the championship are next weekend on Saturday and Sunday, June  and .Niels holds a six-shot lead over George and is  ahead of Stuart in third place.The spokesperson added:#The three will play together in the top group and it will be intriguing to see how the youngster copes with having two club legends chasing him down in the final two rounds.#Donald Laing, home from France for the championship, won the Jim Scally Trophy for the two best handicap rounds over the first two days with -- in round one followed by -- for an excellent combined total of .

story: For some, it is too long ago to remember but, for many, the memories of those dreadful days will never be forgotten.It is wonderful how communities come together during times of tragedy as well as triumph to offer not only practical assistance but emotional support.While it may have been assumed that the families of the victims were grateful for all that was done by the people of Kintyre, from emergency services to members of the community, it must be heartening to hear directly from family members of the men lost.What might be taken as one#s duty at a time of crisis is so appreciated by those affected, even after  years.Even for those too young to remember, the impact of the incident can be felt to this day.Well done to all organisers for sensitively bringing those most affected by the tragedy together at what must have been a very dficult time.

title: down memory lane june 7 2019
story: Springbank Evangelical Church reaches a milestone this year – and is looking back with gratitude over the  years of its presence in Campbeltown.The church is opening its doors for an evening of musical celebration tomorrowat pm, under the ambitious banner of # Years in  Minutes#.Participants will be invited to reminisce in the ied styles of church worship of years gone by, and celebrate together the rich musical heritage that Springbank Church, in particular, has enjoyed over the years.Records show that advertisements were placed in the Campbeltown Courier in the summer of  for meetings to be held on Sunday nights in the Shore Street Hall. The new assembly met there for nine years, until the present building on Longrow was opened in .Since then, there has been an unbroken record of worship and faithful Christian witness. Regular worship followed the traditional Brethren pattern, with the central focus on a short #breaking of bread# service on a Sunday morning, supplemented by a family service. In recent years, the two have been incorporated together in the weekly worship.Many folk from Campbeltown and beyond have come into contact with the church over the years. For some, their memories may be shaped by the time they attended Sunday School this was very popular with more than  attending in the s and s.The Sunday School was headed by Matt Patterson, assisted by Annie McSporran, and the Bible class for teenagers was led by Bob Craig in the s.The extended church building and the arrival of Jonathan and Angela Sharples in the mid-s saw the start of a toddler group, called Jellytots, which became well known to many parents and carers throughout the community.#After I retired, I was involved in the toddler group, along with Pauline Guntripp,# said Felicity Kelly. #It was a happy group, giving parents and carers the opportunity to relax with other adults while the little ones played safely.#When Iain McCallum was pastor of the church, a children’s group – the Rainbow Club – started on a Tuesday evening, with music, activities and crafts for primary school children. The music was provided by Gordon Cosgrove and Katrina Barr.For some, it will have been the youth groups that gave a point of contact with the church. These have existed under ious names – CHAOS with Sam and Jon Philips, Youth Fellowship run by Sian Galbraith and, currently, SKY , led by John Ives and the present pastor, Steve Davies.These have given young people a place to meet together and explore the Christian faith.Steve Davies indicated that the event planned for Saturday evening will aim to blend together three elements: #a historical flavour, a strong musical focus and a thanksgiving celebration#, and he added that there will be a chance to reminisce over refreshments and enjoy a display of photographs showing activities and events of days gone by.A church outing in the s.
